Task: Try your hand at gardening or attend to indoor plants.
Try gentle stretching, yoga, Tai Chi, martial arts, Pilates group or join a gym.
Learn how to play chess.
Help your neighbour.
Dance at home or join a dance group, like bush dancing, rock n roll, belly dancing, jive, ballroom.
Take the stairs instead of the lift or escalator, if possible.
Set a timer to get up and stretch and move morning, midday and afternoon.
Give drumming a go.
Grab a basketball/netball and shoot some hoops.
Try juggling.
Laugh out loud – try a laughter workshop or tell some jokes or try stand up.
Check out the local activities at your local community club.
Play darts, pool or snooker.
Play board games like Monopoly, Scrabble etc
Take on a new role, something new to you.
Attend an open day.
Make some arts and crafts to sell or donate to others to sell.
Attend a local community event, fete or farmer markets or general markets.
Restore a piece of furniture.
Spend some quality play time with pets or children. Offer to baby sit or pet mind for someone.
Offer to volunteer at the local school, helping with reading/studies, mentoring children.
Visit a community centre or senior citizens centre to see what groups and activities are available locally.
Try rock climbing – outdoors or indoors or caving.
Host a quiz event or attend a local trivia event.
Volunteer your skills at community organisations or religious institutions.
Have a clean out and donate some items you don’t use to good will.
Bake a cake and give it to a neighbour or friend.
Volunteer at an animal rescue organisation.
Join a singing group.
Make jams or preserves to keep or as presents.
Try bocce, lawn bowls or ten pin bowling.
Play netball, basketball, squash or table tennis.
Take acting or drama lessons and join a local community theatre group.
Try strength resistance training like weights or weight-lifting.
Take a cooking class or try a different cuisine.
Rearrange or redecorate a room or your house.
Go to a live sports event, even a local match.
Go out for dinner.
Check out open for inspections and auctions.
Volunteer to mentor students or to be a coach or a referee at the local sports club.
Make fresh bread – give your arm muscle a workout and enjoy the benefits.
Walk the dog or neighbour’s dog.
Have a swim at the local pool or river.
Relax or walk in your garden or the local park. Look at changing colours of leaves, bark, tree trunks, bird life.
Walk, jog, run, skip (with or without rope).
Grab a scooter or a bike and go for a ride.
Have walking meetings instead of being indoors.
Get off the bus one stop early or park further away.
Walk or drive a new route.
Fly a kite.
Play Frisbee.
Get out of the city and go camping.
Go for bush walk.
Learn how to drive or ride a motorbike or bicycle.
Learn how to ride a bike and about bike maintenance.
Try a new sport or take lessons such as golf, tennis or a different exercise class.
Go to a march or support local community action groups of your interest.
Go for a hike or climb a mountain to check out the view from the top.
Go for a sail, kayak, canoe, paddle board, wind surf or hire a boat.
Go the mountains to see snow.
Try snow skiing or water skiing.
Hire a motorcycle or sports car for a day.
Play football in the yard or park.
Try horse riding.
Walk along the beach. Build a sandcastle.
Give fishing a go.
Go to raceway.
Go to the races.
Go to the zoo, amusement park or travelling circus.
Try scuba diving or snorkelling.
Try clay pigeon shooting.
Join a social walking or cycle group.
Give go-kart racing ago.
Try busking.
Try out Nordic Walking and join a group.
Organise something new with friends and family members.
Be truly present in a conversation – ask someone about their weekend and maintain eye contact, remove devices or other distractions.
Have a conversation with someone new in the office, school or university.
Phone a relative or friend who needs support or company.
Listen to book online or a podcast.
Read a book, magazine or newspaper.
Have a conversation with someone new in the office, school or university.
Write in a blog, news item, short story, novel, a play or poetry.
Use technology to your advantage at a time that suits you – for example, scroll through social media, online shopping, send a GIF or YouTube clip.
Sing at home, take singing lessons or join a community choir, where no experience is required.
Reach out and connect with a friend you don’t often see.
Have a conversation with older people by asking about their childhood memories or their career.
Join a social groups available online such as. Meet Up groups
Play music or learn an instrument.
Take lessons in another language. Check out what’s available online or from the library.
Nurture yourself by booking in for a massage, facial, manicure or pedicure.
Visit an antique shop and find out about periods.
Do some meal planning – cooking and freezing ahead. Start a food swap with family and friends.
Go for a drive somewhere you haven’t been before, driving a different route.
Find a buddy to talk to about your favourite sport or team.
Plan a day trip to the beach or country.
Have dinner with your family, friends or neighbours or invite everyone to a ‘pot luck’ meal.
Plan a holiday.
Read stories to children or join in childhood chants and games.
Listen to a sermon, lecture or talk at university.
Learn a new card game, play cards or join a card group.
Start a recipe swap group with your family and friends.
Invite a friend/family member for a ‘walk and talk.
Go to a local performance – concert/music, comedy act, theatre, ballet, orchestra.
Catch a bus or train somewhere different.
Try different art mediums eg paint, clay, collage, sculpture, calligraphy, mosaics, sketching, cartoons or photography
Explore short courses available through CIT.
Visit a museum or art gallery.
Go to the movies.
Make some gift cards, candles or soap to keep or as presents.
Go to International Film Festivals.
Go for a walk at lunchtime.
Walk the block or around the lake/pond.
Take walk and notice all the heritage buildings around you.
Meander slowly around town. Do some window shopping.
Collect shells from the beach.
Connect with your own spirituality or religion.
Find old photos of friends and families and share them with them and your recollections of these moments.
Soak in a scented bubble bath with or without candles.
Write a letter, card or postcard and send it by post to a friend or to yourself.
Smile more and say ‘thank you’.
Reflect on the positives that have happened in your day. Write these down.
Send a quick email or text to tell someone to say how much you appreciate them.
Pretend you are someone else – think of what life would be like say a movie star or politician or performer.
Spend time colouring in (colour in books).
Access an online guided mediation or find a DVD at the library.
Enjoy a facial, pedicure, manicure, sauna, spa bath or enjoy a private float tank experience.
Praise those you love and hold dear.
Catch up on your favourite show on live stream.
Open or hold open a door for a stranger.
Try a new recipe or hobby.
Do a jigsaw, crosswords, brush up on your trivia, try Sudoku or different puzzles, whether online or hard copy.
Try sewing, embroidery, knitting, or crocheting.
Research your family history (genealogy).
Learn more about other countries and their flags.
Use a dictionary for words that are new to you.
Research something you have always wondered about. Google it.
Buy a cuppa for a stranger.
Explore ‘do it yourself’ manuals, such as, car maintenance, shares and the stock market, gardening, home maintenance. Check out what’s at your local library on online.
Seek out opportunities for personal or professional development courses.
Ask a colleague/friend how they are and really listen to the answer.
Nominate someone for an award.
Learn or explore technology and what’s available online on webpages apps.
Take notice of what you are thinking and your feelings. Not to judge them but to be more aware of them.
Keep a gratitude journal and write down things you are grateful for.
Revisit or review historical events.
Take 5-10 minutes to concentrate on your breathing.
Be aware of how things feel when you touch them.
Notice the taste of food you eat – chewing slowly, noticing textures, flavours, how the food feels.
Accept a party invitation.
Book in to see a counsellor or life coach.
Learn more about your smart device/s.
Start or join a book club.
Buy some flowers for yourself or pick some from your garden.
Eat a meal in silence.
Find a relaxing scent.
Read poetry.
Let out a couple of big sighs.
Keep a journal and write in it each day.
Join a spiritual/religious group.
Selling or trading items on social media.
Eat nutritious meals.
Find out about growing succulents or bonsai.
Write a list of all your strengths and what inspires you.
Buy something special for yourself, whether at the shops or online.
Visit the local library to see what activities are available or find out all the services available to you, such as, audible books, DVDs, books, home delivery library etc.
Read a new genre of books – something you wouldn’t normally read.
Take a nap or sleep in (don’t set an alarm).
Have media free days or limit media coverage.
Dress up formal for a day and go out for a cuppa.
Have a pyjama day alone at home.
Check out carer social events, activities, and retreats at Carers ACT.
Take some quiet moments in your day to listen to the sounds of nature and enjoy some fresh air.
Connect with nature – walk in the park, look at plants/gardens and trees, watch birds/ducks at a local lake.
Watch a log or campfire.
Notice the sun or rain on your skin, cloud formations and gaze at the stars at night. Watch a thunderstorm.
Take photos of your natural surroundings and revisit them.
Watch a sun set or sunrise.
Sit in the sun with a cuppa.
Try bird watching.
